title: Open Data in a Day
body: This introductory course aims to get you up to speed with latest developments in open data and its significance. It is designed to enable anyone to get started with discovering and using open data and understand the skills and processes required to make it work for you and your organisation.

title: Course overview
body: The course is split into four main sessions. These sessions start by exploring definitions of open data, examines the impacts and future directions of the field, looks at practical aspects such as licencing and best practices and concludes with a hands-on exploration of some key tools.

_items.title: Introducing Open Data
_items.body:
The session explores recent changes in the definition of open data, and allow learners to understand why the current definition has been determined.

The session also examines a number of examples of open data impact from different fields and considers the potential for open data implementation

_items.alt: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments
_items.title: Unlocking data from the web
_items.body: Open data is still a developing field and those working within it will encounter a number of common problems. This sessions presents and clarifys the main challenges before examining the future of open data.

_items.title: Licensing and Best Practices
_items.body:
This session begins by looking at how open licences are there to protect data publishers, while also unlocking value. We show how to build a machine readable open license that can be applied to any online content.

The session then continues by looking at the technical, legal, social and practical requirements for making different types of open data usable and some of the most relevant guidelines to support this process.

_items.title: Cleaning Open Data
_items.body: This session will introduce the importance of recent changes around open data modification rules which help combat data errors. We also introduce OpenRefine and how it improves data management by publishers.

title: The benefits of Open Data
body: This session explores the definition of open data and examines some examples of the benefits of open data. Below to support this discussion you can explore some of the main benefits of open data together with examples.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Support growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, governments need to publish key datasets.

Governments also need to support data infrastructures that connect data with those who use it.

In return, governments are reaping the benefits of a growing data economy as in Finland, where SMEs with access to open data grew 15% faster than those without.

Take me to Finnish case study

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
Governments need to balance the demands of growing populations with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues.

The availability of detailed open data is essential to improve delivery of services at the local level.

Some of these new services are available now -
Take me to mySociety
Take me to the Hungarian 'right to know' portal
Take me to Fix my Street Norway

_items.title: Cost savings
_items.body:
By growing economies and improving services, open data allows governments to make savings in key areas, like provision of healthcare, education and utilities.

In the UK, open data helped reveal £200 million of savings in the health service

In France, energy data is being used to drive more efficient energy generation practices
Show me the France energy data.

Open data can also bring transparency to budgets. In Switzerland, the canton of Bern presented their €400m annual saving to the public using open data

title: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments
displayTitle: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments

title: Challenges of Open Data
body: Open data is still a developing field and faces a number of key challenges which need to be addressed. The following section outlines some of the key areas
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data that is on the web.

_items.title: Inconsistent definitions
_items.body:
Like any new field, open data needs a strong definition to give clarity around what it is and what you can do with it. While many definitions of open data currently exist, promoted by different organisations and meeting different needs, there is no consistency about the terms used in these definitions.

A recent study by GovLab has highlighted the number of different terms used when defining open data in a simple chart that illustrates the need for greater consistency.

_items.title: Lack of proper licences
_items.body:
The majority of datasets described as 'open' still do not have an appropriate licence to protect the ability of everyone to access, use and share them. As of 2015, only around 46% of data in open data catalogues across the European Union is truly openly licensed.

In the EU, copyright and database laws are complex. While data might be intended to be open, a licence provides legal clarity for users.

The OpenDataMonitor platform provides information and statistics on European open data catalogues.

_items.title: Failure to update consistently
_items.body: Simply publishing a dataset is not enough to ensure reuse and relaise the benefits of open data. Datasets also need to be updated at regular intervals to ensure they remain relevant and up-to-date. However, the vast majority of datasets are not updated consistently as shown by the graphics in this study by Thomas Levine.

_items.alt: Confusion between Open, Big and Personal Data
_items.title: Confusion between Open, Big and Personal Data
_items.body: The open data doamin is closely related to the concepts of 'big data' and 'personal data', leading to the terms sometimes being used incorrectly to describe each other. While open data describes what you can do with a dataset (namely access, use and share it), big data is a vendor-driven term used to describe the size of a dataset. finally personal data refers to any data which concerns individuals. It is possible for big data to be open, for personal data to be big and for open data to be personal but all three terms refer to very different things about a dataset. Using these terms correctly and understanding when data is open, big or personal is a key challenge to the understanding of the open data field.

title: Future Developments in Open Data
body: When speaking about open data, it is important to understand the future developments that are emerging at a gloabl level. For this reason, the Open Data Barometer was created to monitor the developments in national open data programmes and present the results as a visual ranking. The Barometer, which can be found here, measures 3 aspects of an open data programme, discussed in greater detail below.
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data from in the web.

_items.title: Open Data Readiness
_items.body:
To what extent is an organisation or country ready to support an open data initiative?

    The following are important indicators of readiness:
  • Open licences supported
  • Policies and procedures established
  • Investments made
  • Educational support available
  • Wider engagement undertaken

_items.title: Open Data Implementation
_items.body:
Data is now as important to our national infrastructure as roads or internet access. For public bodies and governments, there are certain datasets that should be open as a way to support innovation, generate value and grow the economy.

Commercial organisations should also consider which datasets are most useful to help enhance their business and find new market opportunities.

_items.title: Open Data Impact
_items.body:
What are the tangible, real world benefits of the open data for its users?

Without evidence of impact, communities are less likely to grow around the data and innovation can be less widespread. The following are important indicators of impact:

  • Increasing efficiency and transparency of government
  • Economic growth driven by open data
  • Social and environmental benefits

title: Discovering Open Data
body:
The best way to apply your new experience of the open data field is to discover some open data on your own.

To start this process, there is an interactive exercise below. Start by access in the Foreign and Commonwealth Office's Spend over £25000 dataset.

Once you have dataset open,explore the different aspects of the data with this exercise.

title: Why license open data?
body:
Without a licence, data is not truly open.

A licence tells anyone that they can access, use and share your data.

Unless you have a licence, data may be ‘publicly available’, but users will not have permission to access, use and share it under copyright or database laws.

title: Types of licences
body:
The simpler the licence, the better!

There are lots of different licences. To maximise reuse, try to adopt a licence standard that is already widely used.

Take me to a guide on licensing

_items.title: Creative Commons licences
_items.body:
Creative Commons licences are widely used for open content. Version 4.0 explicitly considers data licensing.

There are three Creative Commons versions of an open licence:

  • Public domain: (CC0)
  • Attribution: (CC-BY v4.0)
  • Attribution & share-alike: (CC-BY-SA v4.0)

The public domain and attribution licences give most flexibility in the use of data while a share-alike licence may limit the commercial use of the data.
Show me a Public Domain licence
Show me an Attribution licence
Show me an Attribution & share-alike licence

You can choose a licence that works for you at the Creative Commons website:
Show me how to make my own Creative Commons licence

_items.title: Bespoke/Custom-made licences
_items.body:
A bespoke or custom-made licence is a creation of the data publisher which introduces specific conditions with which the user must comply. Bespoke or custom-made licences can be written by the publisher or adapted from a standard licence through the addition of new conditions and/or the modification of existing ones.

Bespoke and custom-made licences can increase complexity for users of open data.

They may introduce specific conditions that limit usage, restrict data integration and, in some cases, are difficult for users to comply with.

_items.title: Open government licences
_items.body:
Some publishers have chosen to develop their own licences.

The best examples are:

  • short
  • compatible with widely used licences
  • easy to comply with

A good example of a clear open license has been created by the French government.
Take me to the French Government open licence

The UK Government has a good example of an open licence developed in this way that is used by UK Government departments:
Take me to the UK Government open licence

title: Recognising Open Licences
body:
When discovering data online, it is important to be able to check the licence to understadn whether the data is open and if so, under what conditions can you access, use and share it

Take a look at each of the following licences and try to determine whether they are open licences

title: Best Practices
body:
Best practice standards provide users with confidence about the quality and usability of open data.

There are 2 key indicators of open data quality:

_items.title: 5 Stars
_items.body:
The 5 Stars of linked open data include the basic legal definition and technical excellence of the published data.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations on the format and structure of the data.

You can learn more about the 5 Stars in modules 10 and 13 of this course.

_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates are practical, social, legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing or using open data.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers, and in some cases users, to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.
Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site

title: Getting started with Data Cleaning
body:
Data cleaning is essential to ensure that when the data is used, the right conclusions are made.

Often errors are not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over many years. In other cases, errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like mistyping or incorrect abbreviations.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will, however, save substantial time in the long-run.

Follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

Get started with data cleaning in Open Refine

title: Open Data Science
body:
Data science combines advanced data literacy and statistical knowledge with domain expertise. This combination of skills helps derive valuable insights and communicate them to others.

In this course we explored some of the key specialisms of a data scientist, in particular 'data skills', 'machine learning' and 'visualisation'.

The houses dataset provided a solid base for demonstrate and I must thank those behind r2d3.us for putting this excellent data science demo together.

Looking to the future, more data will increase the need to be able to filter it. Perhaps one day we shall all be using tools like Pivot.
